title: DeBUGCN - Detecting Backdoors in CNNs Using Graph Convolutional Networks
author: Akash Vartak (University of Maryland Baltimore County), Khondoker Murad Hossain (University of Maryland Baltimore County), Tim Oates (University of Maryland Baltimore County), ...
relevance_why: The use of Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) for detecting trojaned models can be adapted for more efficient detection systems in audio and speech processing.
background: Detecting malicious backdoor attacks embedded in deep learning models without direct access to the training data.
contribution: DeBUGCN introduces a novel GCN-based pipeline to identify backdoored Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), achieving high accuracy in detection.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on tensor decompositions, which can lose structural information regarding data flow in networks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work represents CNNs as graphs, allowing for accurate and fast detection of trojans using structural and relational data.

key_innovation: Utilizes the structural representation of neural networks as graphs to enable message passing for effective trojan detection.
real_world_impact: This method has significant implications for securing deep learning models in critical applications like autonomous driving and facial recognition, potentially reducing risks from malicious attacks.
limitations: The paper acknowledges that DeBUGCN cannot guarantee immunity against all adaptive attacks since attackers may design specific strategies to evade detection.

new_terms.Backdoor Attack: **A backdoor attack** is a form of malicious manipulation where an adversary embeds hidden triggers in a model's training data to manipulate its output.
new_terms.Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs): **Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs)** are neural networks that operate on graph-structured data, enabling the incorporation of relational information for tasks like node classification.

open_sourcing: All code necessary to reproduce the results can be made available upon publication.
